Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Direct Search for Dark Matter with Underground Argon at LNGS
Award.AbstractNarration:
The existence of dark matter is inferred from gravitational effects, but its nature remains a deep mystery. One possibility, motivated by considerations in elementary particle physics, is that dark matter consists of the hypothesized Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs). It should be possible to detect WIMPs directly, as the orbital motion of the WIMPs composing the dark matter halo pervading the galaxy should result in WIMP-nucleus collisions of sufficient energy to be observable in the laboratory. This collaboration utilizes funds to commission and operate DarkSide-50, a WIMP search using a Liquid Argon Time Projection Chamber (LAr-TPC) with an active mass of 50 kg. DarkSide-50 will use argon extracted from underground sources (Underground Argon, UAr), which this group has shown to have an Ar-39 content lower, by at least a factor of 150, than atmospheric argon. Ar-39 is one of the main sources of background in the experiment.

A significant by-product of this group's research has been developing techniques that could find application in areas ranging from national security to medical imaging. This arises from the extraction of rare noble gases (Argon and Helium) from underground sources, and possible applications include the detection of underground nuclear tests and in Environmental Science where Argon is used as a detection media in ultra-low level proportional counter measurements for an environmental radio tracer for hydrologic transport.

Liquid argon is an attractive medium for WIMP detection due to its efficient conversion of energy from WIMP-induced nuclear recoils into both ionization and scintillation. The argon scintillation time profile ("pulse shape") depends on the type of ionizing particle, providing particle discrimination that can be used to suppress background. Pulse shape discrimination in argon provides one of the most powerful background rejections among all dark matter technologies; when combined with the measurement of ionization, the background rejection is further enhanced.

The proposed activity will advance the development of astroparticle physics and its scientific and educational mission by: (1) offering a continuing excellent opportunity for the training of students, who will contribute to the success of a cutting-edge project; (2) developing techniques that could find application in several areas of benefit to society; and (3) supporting a new education and outreach program, designed to succeed the highly successful Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso-South Dakota-Princeton summer school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
So much of nature is understood at a deep and quantitative level by modern science. Yet the Dark Matter problem remains as a glaring contradiction to the idea that we know everything, and one which has stubbornly resisted decades of assault by scientists. The Dark Matter problem is a set of observational facts showing that the overwhelming majority of matter in the universe (at the level of galaxies and galaxy clusters), must be fundamentally different from the matter we see around us. Furthermore this "dark" matter is completely invisible to us, in the sense that it does not emit or absorb any light or other radiation detectible with instruments. This despite the fact that it has been known for a century that the ordinary matter in stars and distant galaxies is in every way the same as the ordinary matter around us.

 

The DarkSide-50 detector and its successors are a program of experimtnts to directly detect the Dark Matter streaming through our world. Our strategy will succeed if one of the most widely held hypotheses about the nature of Dark Matter is correct- that it is made up of as-yet undiscovered subnuclear particles with the whimsical acronym WIMPs, for weakly interacting massive particles. The work is carried out by an international collaboration with over 100 members from over 20 scientific institutions. My group at Temple has contributed hardware, operations and data analysis work to this multi-year effort.

 

Background from the ``cosmic rays" (high energy particles constantly bombarding the earth from outer space) requires that experiments like DarkSide be carried out deep underground, in our case beneath nearly a mile of rock in the Grand Sasso National Laboratory in Italy. The rock has no effect on WIMPs according to the particle physics models. In this well-appointed underground lab, during this reporting period we have operated two detector systems (DarkSide-10 and DarkSide-50). To further suppress background, the latter detector was surrounded by a huge veto system filled with 1000 tons of ultrapure water. The dark matter detector itself was filled with liquified argon gas, which for technical reasons represents an excellent material for detecting the rare interactions of WIMPs, and distinguishing them from residual background. In a second stage of DarkSide-50, it was emptied and re-filled with special liquefied argon obtained from deep beneath the earth, again to reduce radioactive backgrounds contained in normal argon itself. We have commissioned this elaborate system of detectors, controls, and computers and operated it for nearly 2,000 days of data taking. Alas, we have not detected any WIMPs.

 

However, we have set some of the world's best upper limits on characteristics of WIMPs and these results were accepted and published this year in Physical Review Letters, one of the foremost scientific journals in the world. We have also published numerous other papers describing our techniques and other dark matter search results.

 

There is still room in the particle physics models for WIMP dark matter. The collaboration will continue to pursue it with DS-20K, yet another liquid argon detector at Grand Sasso. This will be about 40 times larger and hence 40 times more sensitive than DarkSide-50. We hope in years to come that the dark matter mystery can finally be solved, by this or another scientific collaboration.

 

Selected DarkSide publications:

1. Wall Street Journal, February 15, 2015, by Gautam Naik "A Cosmic Quest for Dark Matter"

2. Physical Review Letters v. 121 article 111303 (2018) P. Agnes et al, "Constraints on Sub-GeV Dark-Matter-Electron Scattering from the DarkSide-50 Experiment"

3. Physical Review Letters v. 121 article 081307 (2018) P. Agnes et al, "Low-Mass Dark Matter Search with the DarkSide-50 Experiment"

4. Physical Review D v. 98 article 102006 (2018) P. Agnes et al, "DarkSide-50 532-day dark matter search with low-radioactivity argon"

5. Physical Review D v. 93 article 081101 (2016) P. Agnes et al, "Results from the first use of low radioactivity argon in a dark matter search"

6. Journal of Instrumentation v. 12 article P12011 (2017) P. Agnes et al, "The electronics, trigger and data acquisition system for the liquid argon time projection chamber of the DarkSide-50 search for dark matter"

7. Journal of Instrumentation v. 11 article P12007 (2016) P. Agnes et al, "The electronics and data acquisition system for the DarkSide-50 veto detectors"

8. European Physical Journal Plus v. 133, article 131,C. E. Aalseth et al, "DarkSide-20k: A 20 tonne two-phase LAr TPC for direct dark matter detection at LNGS"
